summary_md: This round consolidated structural and algorithmic progress on 3‑coloring circle graphs. Cutting the circle yields an interval-overlap model (adjacency = overlap without containment). For any chord x, G[N(x)] is a permutation graph (hence N(x) and N(x)∩N(y) are permutation), so N(x) must be bipartite in any 3‑coloring. A sweep-line DP / path-decomposition gives k‑colorability in O(n·w·k^w) time and O(k^w) space (w = interval ply), extending to list-coloring and counting; pathwidth ≤ w−1 and degeneracy ≤ 2w−2 (w≤2 ⇒ forest). Pivoting on a chord x yields an exact 2‑SAT formulation for bipartite sides; branching over 2‑colorings of N(x)-components gives overall FPT behavior with a 2^{cc(N(x))} factor. Further corollaries: balanced sweep separator of size ≤ w and ω(G) ≤ w computable in O(n·w·log w). Limits: Ageev’s triangle-free χ=5 examples, ply may be Θ(n). Citations: Research Notes; Current Proofs; Ageev.
one_line_summary: N(x) permutation graphs; k-coloring FPT by representation ply w; pivot test FPT in cc(N(x)).
highlights: Interval model: adjacency = overlap without containment after cutting the circle.
For any chord x, G[N(x)] is a permutation graph; N(x)∩N(y) is permutation (hereditary).
Sweep-line DP / path DP: k-colorability in O(n·w·k^w) time, O(k^w) space; extends to lists/counting; pathwidth ≤ w−1.
Degeneracy ≤ 2w−2; if w ≤ 2 the graph is a forest.
Pivot (bipartite sides): exact 2‑SAT per side; branching over N(x)-component 2-colorings yields FPT with factor 2^{cc(N(x))}.
Balanced sweep separator of size ≤ w and ω(G) ≤ w computable in O(n·w·log w).
next_questions: Implement and benchmark the ply-DP (measure typical w on instances).
Attempt a global 2‑SAT or other compression to remove the 2^{cc(N(x))} branching (or prove obstruction).
Search for hardness gadgets for 3‑coloring within K4‑free circle graphs (use SAT/ILP to aid construction).
